Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 02:57AM kagaines wrote: My eyelashes were one of the first things to grow back...come to find out that it takes about six weeks and they tend to fall out & regrow routinely. (Of course they don't do a mass exodus like they do in chemo.)  The eyebrows are coming back in dark...which makes me really curious as to what the hair on my head is gonna be...looks different each day.  The only hair that hasn't grown back, and I don't care if it doesn't, is the pubic hair.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 02:20AM kagaines wrote: I've not been told anything about using a razor or not, and I did ask at my consult.  They told me using deodarant, a razor, etc - all was okay. I've only got one treatment down and many more to go but if it starts to become a problem I will know.
Posts.Title: Anyone use regular razor on pits during radiation? Stressin67 GardenGirl65

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 04:11AM kagaines wrote: 1. Did you find your lump on your own or did a mammogram pick it up?   I found it, not at the age where mams are the norm yet. 2. Please describe to me what exactly your lump felt like to you or your doctor.  It was firm and didn't move...and there wasn't one in the opposite breast either. 3. Is there a family history?  Not in the immediate family, I was the first.  I had a paternal aunt that had it years ago but that was it as far as I know.
Posts.Title: WHAT did YOUR lump FEEL like? gscott MomOfTeenGirl01

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 09:19PM kagaines wrote: While everyone copes with treatments in different ways, I worked all the way through chemo & now rads.  I had Wednesday & Thursday off at work, so I would do the chemo on Wednesday, and then take a paid day off on Friday, so I would have three days to 'regroup' after chemo.  The rads treatments go alot quicker than chemo does, at least in my thoughts.  It seems like it takes longer to park the car than the actual treatment does.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: anyone worked or gone to school during treatment elsko kagaines

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 04:05AM kagaines wrote: I think it's a crapshoot, to be honest.  I had straight hair pre chemo and now it's came in curly.  I had my last chemo at the end of Sept 2007, and after it coming in curly, it's now starting to go straight again.

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 01:17AM kagaines wrote: Well, I had my second lumpectomy for the DCIS on August 25th.  I was in recovery longer than the surgery.  Always seems to be that way with me & general.  So now it's off to the radiation oncologist to start that whole thing .. again.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 05:49AM kagaines wrote: I had thyroid issues way before breast cancer entered my life.  Comparing the two now, a FNA biopsy that they did for the thyroid was nothing compared to what the breast cancer has entailed.  Hadn't realized there was any connection, though.  I'm without a thyroid now, and that, coupled with the problems I've had from a total hysterectomy, and the breast cancer, have left me in a permanent state of sweating. :( Sending postive thoughts of healing your way...good luck....
Posts.Title: Thyroid Nodule? Msklapkin Honeybear

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 09:32PM kagaines wrote: I just had my port taken out and a surgical biopsy w/needle loc done this past Monday. (June 30th.)  I had the 'twlight drug' also and loved it.  You wake up feeling like you've taken a great nap.  The plus side of it is quicker recovery time than from general, you don't have to be tubed, etc. I was awake as I went into the OR and woke up right as they were finishing up. I'd take twilight anyday over general.
Posts.Title: Are you awake or asleep? snoopygirl karen1956
